slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Hello and welcome to the first session of thisCoding CBT (Computer Based Training).

In this series we will gently introduce you to websecurity, exploring the most common vulnerabilities that can affectwe build and howapply secure coding principles to makemore difficult for attackers.

Now, if you've never heard of or are confused about things such as cross site scripting, cross site request forgery,encoding, … don't worry, these sessions are just what you need to get you started. We'll assume you'reto web application security andbuildfoundation

However, we also understand that time is limited and we do not want to bore you, so these sessions will be short and will move fast enough to keep it interesting but not too fastyou can't follow what happens.

Alright, if you're ready, why don't we just dive in right now? To start with, we'dto introduce you to the following news report...
No notes.

Welcome to Breaking News. Our top story tonight: a major UK bank has been the victim of one of the country’s biggest ever robberies. No guns or weapons were involved, just computers and hackers.

The story broke this afternoon when rumours shot around the city of London about a suspected security breach, involving a bank’s computers, spread around the city of London. Initial investigation suggests that the bank may have been compromised for a number of days. It is currently unclear how many customers have been affected, but suggestions are that it is a significantly high number.

The Prudential Regulation Authority has launched an investigation. Industry insiders suggest that the regulatory body is taking an extremely dim view on the incident. from Scotland Yard’s Central eCrime Unit (PCeU) are also involved in the investigation and have released the following statement:

"Today we became aware of a computer security incident whereupon a large number of customer accounts have been accessed through a Banking Portal and associated Mobile Applications by unauthorised parties. number of fraudulent transactions have been identified, the Central eCrime Unit have been informed and efforts are underway to recover this money. Banking Portal and Mobile Application services are being scrutinised to identify which vulnerabilities might have been exploited by the criminals to compromise accounts."

Hopefully, the scenario we've just introduced in the news report has made youapplication security is relevant to you and what could happen if one of the applications you write were to be hacked and publicly exposed.

But let's just take a widerat why web application security matters not just to you as a developer but to everybody as a society that’s depending more and more on web applications.

Some of you may be old enough to remember the first website built at CERN in 1991:start of the World Wide Web project. This was a static collection of pages with hyperlinks describing how to build websites. Cool, but not so interesting to an attacker.

Now, let’s fast-forward to today. Of course lots has changed. We started doing more interesting things on line, such as e-commerce andbanking. Think of this: when was the last time you went to your bank to make a money transfer? Now, blend in social networks and the advent of the cloud. In no time you'll realise all of these new services rely on an incredible amount of large andweb applications with dynamic content and a mix of frameworks and technologies.

However, this fast-paced evolution of the Web brought about higherof course attractedinterest of the bad guys. If I can hack an online banking portal, I've got potential access to a lot money and personal information, right?

In order to accommodate for this evolution, we had to build larger and more complex applications which in turn rely on a lot of frameworks, which have to constantly get more and more complex to offer better and faster services. And, as I'm sure you've experienced yourself,size and complexitymore and new types of bugs which attackers can find, study and exploit.obviously, with an increased attack surface there's more opportunities there for the bad guys.

But who are the bad guys? They vary in skill levels and motive of course: from your average teenager randomlyautomated scripts on every possible target to more skilled attackers, such as criminal organisations and hacktivists.of course, let's notnation state sponsored attacks. Many large organisations in the last few years have appeared on the news after major security incidents, including Google and Sony.

Now, all ofsounds scary. The good news is that back in 2001 a group of people realised this was coming and foundedOpen Web Application Security Project, also known as OWASP.

OWASP is a community entirely dedicated toapplication security. It includes corporations, educational organisations and individuals from around the world. This community works to create freely-available articles, methodologies, documentation andfor secure web development.

They also maintain a Top 10 list of the most widespreadapplication vulnerabilities, which gets updated every 3 years.

The current 2013 top 10 includes:

A1 Injection
A2 Broken Authorisation & Session Management
A3 Cross-Site Scripting
A4 Insecure Direct Object References
A5 Security Misconfigurations
A6 Sensitive Data Exposure
A7 Missing Function Level Access Control
A8 Cross-Site Request Forgery
A9 Components with Known Vulnerabilities
A10 Unvalidated Redirects and Forwards

Although not in the same order, in these sessions we'll cover these vulnerabilities and how to mitigate them effectively.

Before moving to the next section, let’s take a second to look at some common misconceptions when it comes to application security.

The application is behind a firewall, so it’s secure. This is a false assumption: a well configured firewall will offer some level of protection against network level attacks. However, the firewall will not block traffic directed to the web application, so any application-level attack will still be possible.

The application uses SSL, so it’s secure. Just because the browser shows a padlock, it doesn’t mean that no attacks are possible. Correct use of SSL will indeed ensure that the data transmitted between the server and the user is confidential and will provide users reassurance that they are talking to the authentic server and not a spoofed one. However, application-level attacks, such as the ones we will look at in this course, will still be possible.

As Leonardo Da Vinci once wrote,who loves practice without theory is like the sailor who boardswithout a ruddernever knows where he may cast."

So, before we embark on our journey, let's take a momentlay down some information security foundations and principles which will be our rudder and compass.

To use a common analogy, applications built without security in mind are like bridges constructed without proper foundations and structural integrity checks. They would look like perfect bridges, but they’d fall down at the first flutter of a butterfly’s wings.

In order to build secure applications, we need to apply secure architecture and design principles from the very beginning.

When thinking of information security, the three pillars we need to keep in mind areIntegrity and Availability.

Confidentiality means that access to data is only available to those users who areto see it. For example, when your Internet banking password is transmitted from your browser to the server,wouldn't want any malicious user to be able to eavesdrop on it.

Integrity ensures that data has not been tampered with or altered by unauthorised parties. For example, when sending the results of a credit card transaction to aparty, they need to be able to verify that the outcome of the transaction has not been altered while in transit.

Finally, availability means ensuring that systems and data areto users when they need them.if you needed to perform a time criticaltransfer and all of a sudden your banking portal was not accessible for a prolonged period of time? Would you stick with that bank?
No notes.

Now, what are the core securityto keep in mind when designing, implementing and testing an application?

Input validation and output encoding: as a rule of thumb, consider all input into your application untrusted and perform stricton it.ensure that you correctly sanitise and encode all untrusted data that is output to the user. This alone will mitigate a great deal of vulnerabilities.
Economy of mechanism: try to keep the design and implementation as simple as possible to reduce the likelihood of errors and bugs.

Complete mediation: ensure that all accesses to all resources are checked and authorised.

For example, very often authentication and authorisation are notare enforced by only removing links from the user interface. However,underlying functionality remains available to unauthorised users if they know or can guess the right URLs.

Least privilege:user accounts, processes, servers... these should all be running with the least amount of privilege required to perform their job. For example, should a web server be running with administrative privileges? Probably not!

Defence in depth: experience has taught us that defence mechanisms will eventually fail. For this reason, try to implement multiple layers of defence, so that whenlayer fails, the other layers canyour systemsmuch as possible.

Secure defaults: the default behaviouryour software should be secure. For example, password complexity and ageing requirements should be enforced. Users might be allowed to turn these off, but at their own risk.

Open design: the security of your application should not relyits design or code being kept secret, but upon manyfactors. Otherwise, once the secret is out, if it isn't backed up by secure principles, then the entire security of our applications falls down. A successful example of open design is the Linux operating system: although its design and source code areavailable, when properlyLinux can be very secure and robust.

Fail safe: you should design your security mechanism so that a failure or unexpected event will result in an operation being disallowed.

For example, security methods like isAuthorized(), isAuthenticated(), and validate() should all return false if there is an exception during processing.
No notes.

To be successful in our journey towards more secure applications, we will apply the "Thinking Evil" methodology. This is a skill that doesn't come easily to many developers but it is one that can be learnt. This basically meansyourself in the shoes of the attacker and thinking through all the possible ways you can abuse each and every feature of your application.

In order to help you do this, in the next sessions we will take a lookthe fictitious web portal that you have seen in the news report. We'll guide you through finding and exploiting vulnerabilities from the attackers' perspective. After that we'll see how to applycodingpracticesmitigate and remediate these vulnerabilities.
